explanations.summary: Diastolic pressure depends on how much blood drains from arteries during diastole. Increased aortic elasticity allows better recoil, maintaining diastolic pressure - so INCREASED elasticity would maintain (not decrease) diastolic. Increased TPR slows drainage, raising diastolic. Increased SV raises systolic more than diastolic.

whyCorrect.a: When aortic elasticity INCREASES, the aorta stores more energy during systole and releases it more effectively during diastole, maintaining diastolic pressure. Conversely, DECREASED elasticity (stiff arteries) causes lower diastolic pressure.

whyIncorrect.b: Increased peripheral resistance INCREASES diastolic pressure by slowing blood drainage from arteries during diastole.
whyIncorrect.c: Increased stroke volume primarily increases SYSTOLIC pressure. It may slightly increase diastolic but doesn't decrease it.
whyIncorrect.d: Systolic and diastolic pressures can change independently. Increased systolic doesn't automatically mean decreased diastolic.

explanations.summary: Decreased arterial compliance (stiffer arteries, as in aging) causes: higher systolic (less stretch absorption), lower diastolic (less elastic recoil), and wider pulse pressure. Mean pressure may increase slightly but the key changes are systolic↑, diastolic↓, pulse pressure↑.

whyCorrect.b: Decreased compliance means less elastic recoil during diastole, so diastolic pressure DECREASES. Blood drains faster without the elastic 'squeeze.'
whyCorrect.d: Pulse pressure (systolic - diastolic) INCREASES because systolic rises (less absorption) while diastolic falls (less recoil). This is classic 'isolated systolic hypertension' of aging.

whyIncorrect.a: Systolic pressure INCREASES (not decreases) with decreased compliance because stiff arteries can't absorb the stroke volume.
whyIncorrect.c: Mean pressure may increase slightly but this isn't the primary effect. The hallmark is widened pulse pressure.

explanations.summary: Standing adds hydrostatic pressure below heart level and subtracts it above. Heart level stays ~100 mmHg. Brain (~40 cm above heart): 100 - 30 = ~70 mmHg. Foot (~120 cm below): 100 + 90 = ~190 mmHg. Position DOES affect pressure at different levels.

whyCorrect.a: At heart level, MAP remains ~100 mmHg regardless of position because this is the reference point.
whyCorrect.b: Brain arteries (~40 cm above heart) lose ~30 mmHg hydrostatic pressure: 100 - 30 ≈ 70 mmHg (close to 60).
whyCorrect.c: Foot arteries (~120 cm below heart) gain ~90 mmHg: 100 + 90 = 190 mmHg.

whyIncorrect.d: Position DOES affect pressure at different body levels due to hydrostatic effects. Only heart-level pressure stays constant.

explanations.summary: MAP = CO × TPR (directly proportional to both). MAP ≈ diastolic + 1/3(pulse pressure). MAP typically INCREASES with age (arteriosclerosis). Standing adds ~80 mmHg hydrostatic pressure to foot arteries (100→180 mmHg).

whyCorrect.a: MAP = Cardiac Output × Total Peripheral Resistance. Directly proportional to both.
whyCorrect.b: MAP ≈ Diastolic + (Pulse Pressure/3) because diastole is longer than systole (~2/3 of cardiac cycle).
whyCorrect.d: Standing adds hydrostatic column (~80-90 mmHg for foot distance from heart), changing foot artery pressure from ~100 to ~180 mmHg.

whyIncorrect.c: MAP typically INCREASES with age due to arterial stiffening and increased TPR, not decreases.

explanations.summary: Pulse pressure = Stroke Volume / Arterial Compliance. DECREASED compliance (stiffer arteries) INCREASES pulse pressure. Decreased SV would decrease PP. Decreased blood volume decreases SV, decreasing PP. Heart rate alone doesn't directly increase PP.

whyCorrect.d: Decreased arterial compliance means the same stroke volume causes a larger pressure rise. PP = SV/C, so lower C = higher PP. This is why elderly have wide pulse pressure.

whyIncorrect.a: Decreased stroke volume would DECREASE pulse pressure (PP = SV/C).
whyIncorrect.b: Decreased arterial blood volume reduces venous return and stroke volume, decreasing pulse pressure.
whyIncorrect.c: Increased heart rate alone doesn't directly increase pulse pressure. It may slightly decrease it by reducing filling time and SV.

explanations.summary: The arterial pressure pulse wave travels at ~5-8 m/sec (much faster than blood flow at ~0.5 m/sec). It's created by ventricular ejection into the aorta. It reaches the wrist ~0.1 sec after ejection. Wave velocity ≠ blood flow velocity.

whyCorrect.a: Pulse wave velocity is ~5-8 m/sec in young adults (faster in stiff arteries of elderly).
whyCorrect.b: The pressure pulse is generated when the left ventricle ejects blood into the aorta, stretching the arterial wall.
whyCorrect.c: The pulse reaches the radial artery (wrist) ~0.1 seconds after ventricular ejection due to the ~5 m/sec wave speed over ~50 cm distance.

whyIncorrect.d: Pulse wave velocity (~5 m/sec) is much FASTER than blood flow velocity (~0.5 m/sec in aorta). They're independent phenomena.

explanations.summary: Decreased compliance (stiff arteries): systolic↑ (less stretch), diastolic↓ (less recoil), pulse pressure↑ (wider gap). Mean pressure effect is variable. Classic pattern of aging/arteriosclerosis.

whyCorrect.c: Diastolic pressure DECREASES because stiff arteries have less elastic recoil to maintain pressure during diastole.
whyCorrect.d: Pulse pressure INCREASES: systolic rises (less absorption) while diastolic falls (less recoil), widening the gap.

whyIncorrect.a: Systolic pressure INCREASES (not decreases) because stiff arteries can't stretch to absorb stroke volume.
whyIncorrect.b: Mean pressure change is less predictable and not the primary consequence of decreased compliance.

explanations.summary: Stiff arteries (decreased compliance) = higher systolic, lower diastolic, wider pulse pressure. This is isolated systolic hypertension of aging. Mean pressure may rise but pulse pressure widening is the hallmark.

whyCorrect.a: Diastolic pressure DECREASES with decreased compliance due to reduced elastic recoil during diastole.
whyCorrect.c: Pulse pressure INCREASES dramatically because systolic rises while diastolic falls.

whyIncorrect.b: Systolic pressure INCREASES, not decreases, with stiff arteries.
whyIncorrect.d: Mean pressure change is secondary to the marked pulse pressure widening.

explanations.summary: During arterial transmission, the systolic peak actually INCREASES (amplification) due to wave reflection and vessel tapering. High frequencies are damped, diastolic component changes, and pulse amplitude depends heavily on compliance.

whyCorrect.f: Systolic pressure amplitude INCREASES during transmission from aorta to peripheral arteries (pulse amplification) due to wave reflection from branch points and vessel tapering.

whyIncorrect.a: High frequency damping occurs but this alone isn't correct as the single answer.
whyIncorrect.b: The diastolic component changes but this statement is incomplete.
whyIncorrect.c: Arteriolar dilation can cause pulsations in capillaries but this isn't always 'significant.'
whyIncorrect.d: True but not the single correct answer here.
whyIncorrect.e: True - compliance greatly affects pulse amplitude - but not the single correct answer.

explanations.summary: Increased TPR: caused by sympathetic vasoconstriction, raises BOTH systolic and diastolic proportionally (not preferentially systolic), so pulse pressure stays relatively unchanged. TPR increase actually impedes venous return (doesn't promote it).

whyCorrect.a: Increased sympathetic activity causes arteriolar vasoconstriction, increasing TPR.
whyCorrect.e: Increased TPR raises both systolic and diastolic pressure proportionally, so pulse pressure (the difference) stays relatively unchanged.

whyIncorrect.b: Increased TPR raises diastolic MORE than systolic (or equally), not less. Diastolic is especially sensitive to TPR.
whyIncorrect.c: Pulse pressure doesn't increase significantly with TPR changes alone - both pressures rise together.
whyIncorrect.d: Increased TPR impedes venous return by backing up blood in arteries. It doesn't promote venous return.
